segments.text: I don't know how this is going to tie in with an article on Chad Oliver, other than it's your opinion.
Well, I guess I ought to set the stage and qualify it a little bit.
Never met John Kim.
During the period that I was writing a lot for a Stanley Analog under various titles, John and I corresponded prodigiously.
and I gather this is more or less a requirement if you're going to write for Campbell, is that you get involved in these endless arguments and discussion by mail.
I don't know how he does it, you know.
I mean, he used to send me fantastic letters, you know, 27 pages single-spaced.
I remember one of them was, and
this is a busy man, you know, I don't know how he does it.
You know, John, he still reads, I guess, everything that comes in himself, unless it's just obviously illiterate.
I guess that's what the assistant editor does, is weed out the stuff that is just hopeless, you know, and he reads everything else, and he writes tremendously about it.
That's one qualification.
The other qualification is that I, as I said, I haven't read
or kept up with the field like I used to, and this includes the editorials and analog, which I suppose is what you're really talking about.
So I can't comment very specifically.
Let me just say this, that Camel was probably the single most influential man in the development of what we call modern science fiction.
I mean, it seems to me this is beyond argument, but

if Campbell had not come along when he did and done what he did with Astounding, the whole course of science fiction would have been, I think, radically different, and I think his influence was definitely beneficial.
That isn't what you want me to say, I know, but apart from everything else, he was an amazingly creative editor.
Not in the sense that Tony Boucher was.
I mean, Campbell's talent is not in taking a manuscript,
and saying, well, this is what's wrong with it.
Do this, that, and the other, but we're going to do it your way.
Campbell's talent is in finding writers and in stimulating them to make them want to write for him.
And one way he does this, it's exactly the same way McAllister teaches.
McAllister used to call it education by irritation.
Campbell has exactly the same pitch.
Well, what he does is he throws out these

controversial statements and remarks, and where he gets you so mad that you sit down with a typewriter and write a story to refute him, or agree with him if that's the case, but in any case, he gets you involved.
And after all, look at the writers that this guy found.
It's fantastic.
That's one side of Kim.
I respect him, I admire him, I really do.
I don't know.
I suppose ultimately it comes down to what your view of science fiction is and how important you think it is.
But if you once grant the premise that it is worth something, there's nobody that's more responsible for what it is today than John Campbell.
Okay.
Negative side.
The thing that always annoyed me the most about John, and it's something that I...

really found almost incomprehensible in a man who was a writer himself, and a rather good one too, not so much under his own name, but as Don Stewart, he wrote some fine things, is his total lack of concern with writing quality.
He doesn't care, at least as far as I can determine, if he likes the idea
And if it's written just well enough to hold somebody's attention, that's apparently all he demands.
And I really am not sure that it's so much a hostility on John's part toward fancy writing, trick writing as he often calls it, literary writing, that sort of thing.
I don't really think that's it.
I think he just doesn't give a damn.
And if he got a story that was written in trick prose and it happened to be about something that really punched one of his buttons and it was comprehensible to his readers, I guess he'd print it.
But he's just not interested in writing.
He's not interested in literary quality.
And this I find hard to take.
And it's one of the
One of the reasons for the curious status of analog right now, and here's a magazine that in a way is the best magazine in the field.
In a sense, I guess it still has a bigger circulation than any other science fiction magazine.
You pick it up and there won't be a name on the contents page you ever heard of before.
None of the big names in science fiction write for analog, and yet this is the showcase of the film.
Maybe he knows what he's doing.
With regard to the editorials, that's a different can of worms.
John has always been or always liked to think of himself as being an iconoclast, an individual, idiosyncratic, always going against whatever the popular current might be.
He has this image of himself.
And I don't know.
Nobody agrees with everything that John Campbell says.
I doubt that John himself agrees with all of it.

And the reaction I get is that John is one of these guys that just automatically opposes the popular point of view, whatever it is, the easy point of view, and is always trying to make an argument on the other side.
I think a lot of what he says is highly dubious.
The alleged racism, for example,
A number of other things.
I don't share John's interest in psi factors and all this stuff, and we used to argue endlessly about this.
I think John has lots of peculiar ideas about history, for example, certainly about anthropology.
But at the same time, you've got to say that this is no fool.
A lot of what John says makes sense, even if he does push it further than most people would push it.

And he does have a talent for not being impressed by a lot of fancy names, not being impressed by a lot of footnotes and verbiage, but going to the heart of the argument and saying, hey, wait a minute.
Have you ever tried looking at it this way?
And it's not a popular thing to do.
It's a hard thing to do.
And maybe it's worth doing, whether you agree with him or not.
So what?
What a terrible world this would be if everything was so blame him.
that everybody had to agree with every statement that he makes.
And God knows the remarks that Campbell makes aren't nearly as controversial as lots of remarks that are made on the other side.
That's quite true.

It's also a footnote becoming rather more respectable, some of it, in that for a long time John has questioned this idea that everything in human behavior is a matter of conditioning, a matter of culture, which was a stock
involvement of the social sciences for years.

Now on a popular level along come people like Robert Argery and Desmond Morris, and on a scientifically more respectable level I suppose you get people like Conrad Lorenz and a number of anthropologists, Sherry Warshburn, who are saying exactly the same thing.
And John's arguments are not totally nonsense.
and said he's taking his lumps now.
Who's he taking them from and about what?
Primarily these people you would classify as new waivers who are against the very things you've been talking about now.
It's nothing new.
It's been happening a while.
And his magazine still has the highest circulation by far.
John just doesn't care about that kind of writing.
And as I say, maybe the guy knows what he's doing.
Most people, when they pick up a magazine, they want to read a story.
Most people, to tell you the truth, don't have any idea whether the writing quality is good, bad, or indifferent anyway, as long as they can get through it.
But just the same, for a guy who was a writer, it's surprising he's not more concerned with it than he is.
Given the choice, however, mind saying this, if I were just going to pick up one magazine to read on my way home tonight, it would probably be Analog.
You haven't been, probably haven't seen the fantastic, I believe it is, where Alexia Panchin is getting into the criticism of science fiction.
No, I have not.
It's got an interesting series going there in that magazine, which you might find of interest in some kind.
Well, yeah, thanks, I will.
Yeah, we really...
We almost never had a critic in science fiction, really, until Damon Knight came along.
And I disagree emphatically with Damon.
But he did some very worthwhile things.
I think his essays on Van Vogt, for example.
The only trouble with Damon's criticism is that he doesn't have the talent that Boucher had.
He destroyed the writer.
if you're at all sensitive to criticism, you know, you read what Damon has to say about you, gosh, you go slink away in the night and never write another line.
Tony had this marvelous facility, you know, even if he didn't like something, of making you want to go on, and not only that, but helping you, giving you some concrete suggestions.
The trouble with Damon, and don't quote this, please, I was asked to review a book of Damon's short stories one time by Doug Parker.
who's now chairman of the classics department here.
I don't know if you know Doug or not, he's a big science fiction fan.
He was out at the University of California in Riverside where he had a book review column in the paper and reviewed science fiction.
He asked me to review a book of Damon's one time and I finally just declined because I couldn't think of anything good to say about it.
He admires a kind of a bloodless, technically expert, to me utterly trivial kind of a story.
When you get to a question of anything about impact or something that hits the gut or something like that, Damon doesn't know what you're talking.
He doesn't even know what you're trying to do, much less whether you succeeded or not.
And I find it very debilitating.
But just the same, until Damon came along, there was very little intelligent comment on science fiction.
And what he has to say is intelligent.
It's interesting.
I just think he's dead wrong.
That's it.
Blish seems to be the primary critic right now.
Yeah.
Well, Blish is another one.
I mean, who is James Blish?
He's a James Joyce scholar, among other men.
And if you've ever met Blish, or read anything about him, he's another one of these rather bloodless, terribly cerebral types.
And, you know, is this all science fiction?
You know, it
It was a stock criticism that was leveled at science fiction for years, mostly by people who didn't know anything about it.
But there is a grain of truth in it, that the one area that is so deficient is in characterization.
There are no recognizable human beings in here.
In fact, somebody once made the comment, fairly perceptively, that the robots and androids are the most human people in science fiction.
And on the other hand, that it was...
so terribly intellectual and cerebral that it just never had any force or power.
And it seems to me that the ideal fiction of somebody like James Blish or Damon Knight is precisely this kind of fiction.
It's dead.
And you ask, well, what did Damon Knight ever write?
The best story Damon ever wrote is a joke.
I mean, literally a joke.
You know, not with a bang.
You know, the one about the last man and the last woman.
Well, I suppose part of the problem is that you've got to face this about yourself.
I'm the aberrant one.
I'm quite unlike most science fiction writers that I know, for better or for worse.
And I've...
I've worked rather largely isolated from the mainstream, or whatever you want to call it.
And my conception of what science fiction should be and the kind of book I want to write is very different from what most of them are trying to do.
That's just the way it is.
And I guess it's only natural that I happen to like what I'm trying to do, not saying I'm doing it correctly.
And I've never read any criticism in science fiction.
that really struck me as being addressed to the same set of problems that I would address if I were writing, but I'm not going to write, so I'm going to leave it at that.
Maybe a loss for science fiction as a- You do have- Tony came closer.
Tony wasn't a critic, he was a reviewer, his own phrase.
But the great quality that he had was that he was so eclectic.
The amazing thing about Tony was he could see merit in widely different types of stories.
Tony would love anything from Mission to Gravity to More Than Human, you know, and see no problem there.
If Tony were still alive, he'd love the new wave.
I don't think there's any doubt about it.
But at the same time, he'd like the old wave, too.
And maybe that's what we need.
But you know, this whole new wave business, you can't really divorce it from the rest of literature.

It's really a sign that science fiction is less ingram than it used to be, and that you have a number of people who are writing science fiction, but aren't just science fiction writers, and they're concerned about what's happening in literature generally, whether you like it or not is another question.
There's some modern things I like very much.
I mean, apart from science fiction, although I'm terribly dated by modern things.
I like Lawrence Durrell's Alexandria Quartet.
I thought it was superb.
And I don't know what the hell you'd call it, but it's certainly not a traditional piece of fiction.
I like Catch-22.
And I like Dyke's Rabbit Run, although I thought the big sex novel was a disaster.
I think...
What's the name of it?
Couples.
An utter mystery to me, how a guy with the talent that that guy has could write Couples, except I know the answer perfectly well, he made 20 times.
I was just going to say, great big dollar sign.
But he can flat write, no question about it.
This is probably the most disorganized interview you've ever conducted, if you can make head or tail out of this stuff.
Well, I'm not an accomplished interviewer.
It's probably obvious.
I've not attempted it very often, and probably won't attempt it too much more.
Well, I hope I haven't scared you off for the rest of your life.
Oh, no.
It's just an area you have to learn in, as anywhere else.
No, you're doing fine.
I meant that as a criticism of me, not of you.
My voice is gradually... You're picking out a lot of... You're adding many things to the questions that really are...
You'd get a messy answer.
Yes or no of the witness, then.
Just out of curiosity, and again, probably not related to the article, but have you done anything with your manuscripts, or have you made any plans to do anything with your manuscripts?
No.
It was only, well, I don't know, four years ago, something like that,
but suddenly the notion percolated that these might have some value.
And I haven't kept a tremendous amount from the early days.
I've got some.
I've got some boxes of stuff in Kerrville.
I don't even know what's in them.
But the last time I looked through there, there were a lot of original manuscripts and some working notes and things like that.
But for the last four or five years,
I've kept everything.
I've kept working notes and first drafts and typescripts and notes to myself and everything else as I was working along on the stories.
So I will have it in the future.
In the past, it's pretty sporadic.
I don't know what I've done, but I think I've got the original manuscripts of almost everything I've ever written.
At least a carbon of it.
As to what I'm going to do with them ultimately, I don't know.

I was just curious, I know Syracuse is very actively interested in acquiring, and I know UT, of course, which you might have a particular feeling for, is very interested in keeping Texas writers at home, so to speak.
When I was here and talking to people.
I haven't, it really isn't even fair to say I haven't made a decision.
I haven't even thought about it.
I've just gotten to the point where I've stopped throwing things away.
And what I would do with it ultimately, I just don't know.
You worry about that ultimately.
Yeah, I worry about it ultimately.
I think a lot of it would really depend, just like any writer, on whether there was some place at some time that had a specific interest in my stuff.
where I have a feeling that if I did give it or if they bought it or whatever they did with it, it wouldn't just sit in a box somewhere.
It might be useful to someone.
Outside of your personal papers, what sort of a science fiction library do you have?
Do you still have your old pulps?
Yeah, not here.
I'm in the process of trying to design a study for myself.
We've got 15 acres of land out here off BK Road, a very small house.
I originally had one room in there I could use as a study, but that was before my son came along.
He's three years old.
Well, I've got now, I've got a desk and a bedroom, which is about where I started out years ago.
And we just don't have a room.
to store things in the house.
But when I get the study built finally and I can get all the stuff together, I'll bring it up.
It's almost all in Kerrville.
And to answer that, I've got, during the period where I was reading everything, I kept everything.
And from, well, I don't know, 41, 42, whenever it was,
on through, I guess, the middle 50s.
I've got virtually everything.
Magazines, paperbacks, hard bans, the works.
Prior to that date, I have scattered stuff.
I went back and I bought a lot of early amazing stories and wonder stories and weird tales and things like that.
I kept all that.
I'd say that the collection is probably very good.
up through about maybe 1955, 1956, and very scattered since then.
I just don't buy anything like the number of books and magazines that I used to, but virtually everything I glom onto I keep.
It's getting difficult to buy three or four hundred new books a year.
It's fiction.
Aside from the expenses.
The early stuff, I think it would probably be a pretty interesting library.
There's somebody in the, you know, I have things, you know, The Outsiders and things like that.
In fact, I've got that whole early run up from Arkham House.
And I've got things like Ray Cummings' old books, like, you know,

The Conqueror, and The Sea Girl, and all that stuff, and all of Burroughs' stuff back in the old cloth band, the early editions, and just about everything else that popped up, all the early anthologies and things like that.
That's good.
I think that ought to tie it up for now.
We've taken plenty of your time.
It's been a pleasure.
I hope I've given you what you want and not too much of what you don't want.
Well, as I said, as is the case usually with me, I'll probably have to come back with some questions if you would not answer them.
I'd be delighted.
And I want to apologize and explain to you why I've been so difficult to get hold of.
The bulk of it is simply the old stock story about I've been too busy.
And the weekends, I've gotten to the point where I'm under so much pressure all week that come Saturday I just like to take off and what I'm doing is nothing more stimulating than going fishing.
But I really have gotten to the point where I need it.
So I'm not usually available on weekends, but where I am, it's down on the river.
But I am sorry that it's taken so long to get together.
Well, it's been no problem from my standpoint.
I'll have to go over this many times, and I have the time, so no problem at all.
I'm just hoping that I'm going to have the time in the next few years to get back and really do some rockin'.
Well, six or eight novelettes are all worked up and ready to go with no time to write them.
And I have a couple of other novels that I want to write.
I think the next one probably will not be science fiction, but the one after that will be.
And I don't know.
Things are bound to be better in the next four years than they've been in the last four years.
It's been a bit of a drag.
Okay, well, I appreciate the problems of the department, Chairman.
It's been fantastic.
Not as bad in a way this year as the previous three because there's been so much chaos in the administration.
This past year has almost been a holding operation where the big problem has been to avoid doing things because no matter what you try to do, you're going to turn them.
In fact, well, let's just wait a while on that.
But that can have its problems too.
But for three years, I put in a long day every day in the office.
You'd look back at the end of the day and ask yourself, well what the hell did I do that was useful?
That's pretty hard to point at anyway.
But it's ending.
That's good.
You're going back.
There will be a new chairman.
There'll be a new chairman.
But actually, I'll be through as a
or around the 1st of June because there will be an acting chairman that will take over the summit.
Who's going to be the headman?
Yes, his name is Jerry Epstein.
Oh, Dr. Epstein is?
Yeah, you know Jerry.
Well, we can look forward to you having some time.
Well, I hope so.
It's bound to be more time than I've had anyway.
I joined the N3F this past year for the first time just out of curiosity more than anything.
I'm not really active in fandom other than the fact that it gives me a lot of information.
It's been going on for a long time, you know.
It really has.
I'm learning more about it and becoming more interested.
But among other things, I noted that I collected the works of Chad Oliver and in the welcome committee letters, many people commented that
It's too damn bad, Chad Oliver's not writing some more.
For what it's worth.
I thank you for passing that on.
You're not forgotten, that's for sure.
Well, it helps to know that, believe me.

I get letters occasionally from people who have read my stuff, and they always begin in effect like, gee, I apologize for imposing on your time, but I'd just like to say such and such, and my god, that's what you live for.
I'm pleased that you liked it.
If I understood you correctly, I don't know what kind of a reaction it's going to get.
It's very odd.
I'm indexing all reviews of science fiction books that appear in science fiction magazines and in Library Journal and Publishers Weekly and so forth, so I'll pass on any reviews that I run across.
Just pass on a good one.
The only bad thing about this book was that

I wrote to Kay Kidd, who's the senior editor at Cigna, and a wonderful gal, and just been great to work with, and she just moved heaven and earth to get this published and hard down in this country, and it fell through at the last minute.
But a wonderful gal, and I pointed this out to her.
I wrote actually about it.
One sentence was in there.
Yeah, that's right.
I wrote actually about the cover, and I said that I liked it a lot, and I'd like to get the original if I could.
And I just mentioned that I wished I could say the same for the blurred copy.
Specifically, it's not designed to appeal to anybody who might for any reason want to pick up the book.
has nothing to appeal to a science fiction reader, has nothing to appeal to anybody who's interested in conservation, ecology, whatever you want to call it, which is a theme that runs all through.
Instead, it's the killing time for the big people.
What the hell was that?
It's like you just thumbed through the book at random and picked out a sentence.
Yeah, I think it's terrible.
But the next, the other question I have is, they quote Anthony Belcher here, do you have
Any knowledge of where or when that review?
If I'm not mistaken, I think they've got it wrong in that I don't think that was in the New York Times, although it may have been.
It may have been in connection with a review of one of my books.
I think he wrote it in the magazine of fantasy and science fiction, where the quote actually came from.
Bill Nolan dug it up and used it, I think, in Three to Three as a Highest Power, and that's where they picked it up.
But if I'm not mistaken, it didn't come from the New York Times, except in the sense that he was working for the New York Times.
My recollection of it is rather vague, but I think it was in the introductory blurb to one of my stories in Fantasy and Science Fiction that he originally wrote that.
What would you say would be the reaction of Bill Nolan if we would write to him about your bibliography?
See how many gaps we've got?
I'm curious.
We'd probably be told.
Any idea where we might write him?
Yeah, except I don't have it.
I don't have his address here.
I do at home.
I'd be glad to call you.
tomorrow and give it to them.
I appreciate it.
Just for goodness sakes, don't mention anything about my reactions.
Oh no, I just said other than we visited with him and we've been trying to file one and a pair of notes or nothing else.
I'm not sure he'd be doing it.
And I'd be glad to give you his address.
I'm sorry, I just don't have it.
That's quite alright.
I'd like to ask a favor of you.
I gave this to Lan Hewlett, our academic counselor over there.
I said give his regards.
I know Lan.
And a man
Took it from my desk Saturday.
He was helping us work at the basketball tournament.
Took it home with him to finish reading.
Didn't tell me about it.
Told one of my bosses.
And so he made a special trip home to get it today so I could bring it over and if you would autograph it for Lan.
To Lan?
Uh-huh.
Here's a pen.
Yeah, I need it.
These paperbacks are...
I saw that the, excuse me, the...
We've thoroughly addicted him to your writing, by the way.
I met him today for the first time.
Oh, he's a nice guy.
I'm sorry to hear about his wife.
Yeah, that was at the UCLA football game just before the game began.
She dropped dead of a heart attack.
Yeah, I understand.
Maybe I'd better borrow your pen.
He was writing.
Now, that explains his talent.
He's left-handed, too.
Aha!
I accuse my wife, who's also left-handed, of having been born backwards.
Well, I had a football coach in high school who used to say, Shad, as he always called me, you are no-handed.
And in a way, it's the truth.
I'm almost ambidextrous.
I write left-handed, and I'm slightly better casting with a fly rod with my left hand, but I do almost everything else right-handed.
